sect1.title: Impact of Gender, Race, Culture, Age, and Other Aspects of Diversity
sect1.para: When assessing a client for an anxiety disorder, there are many individual factors (e. g., gender, culture, age) that may impact the presentation and assessment of the disorder. Awareness and consideration of these factors may help increase the validity of a suggested diagnosis, especially for individuals whose identities may have been historically underrepresented in clinical research.

The degree to which the interviewer and client differ in cultural (and subcultural) background, and in their positionality in society, the interviewer should hold their conceptualization of the client’s problems lightly. This conceptualization includes the two-component behavioral framework described here. Our understandings of the world (including our social world) attempt to reduce complexity to more manageable within the limits of human cognition; the DSM and behavioral two-component frameworks are reductionistic. Awareness of the potential usefulness of these frameworks should be balanced with an awareness of their limitations as cultural constructs.

Even after the assessment is complete, the imperfect reliability of our diagnostic procedures warrants viewing the diagnosis as provisional, subject to confirmation or correction using information from the client during therapy. The diagnosis of anxiety disorders, and the behavioral conceptualization that is implied by the diagnostic label, can be viewed as a frame that is possibly useful to the client. The diagnosis should not be reified. It is descriptive, and like any description, it is incomplete. Clinicians are typically in positions of power over clients, positions that include expertise if not authority. The positionality that comes with the roles of clinician and client creates the potential for the clinician’s pronouncements to negate the client’s experience. Therapy can be viewed as the process by which the client can learn about a new conceptualization of their problem, but the client is the ultimate arbitrator as to whether that new conceptualization is useful to them. During therapy, the clinician can invite the client to engage in new behaviors to find out if the new conceptualization fits with their experiences. Clinicians need not abandon their beliefs in order to adopt a collaborative approach—they should have humility about the complexity of the human experience and about their own beliefs.

sect2.title: Sex, Gender, and Sexual Orientation
Older Adults
Children and Adolescents
sect2.para: A recent national survey found that 7.8% of children ages 3 to 17 in the United States reported symptoms of a current anxiety disorder disorder (US Department of Commerce, 2021 ). Some diagnoses are found almost exclusively in children including selective mutism and separation anxiety disorder. When assessing symptoms of anxiety disorders in children, it is important to be aware of behaviors like tantrums, irritability, and crying which may be misattributed to disobedience rather than than an anxiety disorder. Distress and avoidance manifest in varied forms, and that variation is greater among populations with less developed verbal abilities and skills. Children are also more likely to report physiological symptoms of anxiety like headaches and gastrointestinal distress (APA, 2022 ). Additionally, children may have a hard time identifying their avoidant behaviors, so reports from parents and teachers may be particularly important. Developmentally appropriate fears and worries should not be considered as evidence of an anxiety disorder. Measures specifically designed for assessing anxiety disorders in children include the Youth Anxiety Measure for DSM-5 (YAMS-5; Martinez-Snyder et al., 2023 ; Muris et al., 2017 ) and the Patient Health Questionnaire—Adolescent (Johnson et al., 2002 ).

sect2.title: Race and Culture
Socioeconomic Status
Intersections of Identities
sect2.para: Many clients hold one or more of the identities referenced in this section. It is important for clinicians to be aware of how intersecting identities may impact the frequency and presentation of anxiety disorders. For example, the previously identified sex differences in diagnosed anxiety disorders have been shown to decrease for individuals over the age of 65 notably. This change in prevalence is hypothesized to be due to a number of factors including the impact of mortality-related anxiety anxiety , difficulty differentiating anxiety from age-based cognitive decline, and hormonal changes associated with the end of the female reproductive cycle (Krasucki et al., 1998 ). During the assessment process, the clinician should consider the client’s identity as a whole within their current context to develop a more comprehensive case conceptualization and diagnosis.
